The Create-athon will provide a design challenge for groups to creatively address with a digital media proposal. The design challenge will allow students to apply their growing skillset to simulated realistic scenarios.  
https://t.co/EmOgbuXsrL
#Createathon #carleton_u https://t.co/CZRnG2Z64l

Like Game Jams and Hackathons, the Create-athon is a short sprint event for groups to develop a digital media proposal/prototype that creatively meet a design challenge. The events emphasize creative thinking and collaboration.
https://t.co/EmOgbuXsrL
#Createathon #carleton_u https://t.co/3rfc0SSDqc

BMPD is hosting the inaugural Create-athon on April 29-May 2. The 4-day hybrid event will have BMPD student groups compete for a $500 prize to create a digital media proposal answering a design challenge.
Learn more and Register: https://t.co/EmOgbuXsrL 
#Createathon #carleton_u

Have you checked out the online exhibition "Retrospective" by BMPD instructor and post-doctoral fellow Sojung Bahng? This exhibition examines fragility, affect, relationships and vulnerability through film, moving imagery, and virtual reality. 
https://t.co/az0wdZKBVS
#carleton_u https://t.co/ADBLA6gNEw

Want to learn how to create AR filters using Snap Lens Studio? Check out the latest BMPD Storyteller Post by Jada Rodgers who explores AR as a digital storytelling tool. 
#BMPDstorytellers #AR https://t.co/vnG72X8vQn

New BMPD Storytellers post! Check out https://t.co/iZxanQmrB8 to see how augmented reality filters fit on the reality-virtuality continuum and watch a tutorial to use Lens Studio to create SnapChat filters!
#BMPDstorytellers https://t.co/hKMd9XBBW4

Post-doctoral fellow and instructor Sojung Bahng is the founder/director of Artengine that focuses on how practice-based research is applied to creative disciplines and connect artists, creators, scientists, and researchers. https://t.co/siYkWQudnc
#carleton_u #carleton_research https://t.co/82qSKI41Fm

BMPD Instructor, Katie Graham, is associate faculty at CIMS. The research lab has four streams of inquiry: digitalization, modelling, digitally assisted fabrication, and digitally assisted storytelling. 
@thecimslab #carleton_research #carleton_u https://t.co/1hBB1lBdK0

Another research lab associated with BMPD faculty is the INCLUDE Lab, lead by Dr. Vicky McArthur. It focuses on Inclusive Design for interactive media to encourage developers to design applications for the full range of human diversity.
#carleton_U #carleton_research https://t.co/ONlgxegjZJ

Let's talk about faculty research! Professor Stéfy McKnight is Director and founder of PROTOHYVE, a resource-based centre for research, that invites collaboration between research-creationists and labs across Turtle Island. 
 https://t.co/FrP0qJ6QDo
#carleton_research #carleton_u

VR is currently experiencing an explosion in popularity - and with it comes the exciting rhetoric about the ‘metaverse’ and its implications for the future. Learn more in this week's BMPD storyteller's podcast featuring Sojung Bahng. 
https://t.co/ABUJnc0hBA
#BMPDstorytellers https://t.co/PxML9N1KGY

Time for another BMPD Storyteller Podcast! In episode 5,  Max interviews Sojung Bahng - BMPD postdoctoral fellow and award-winning artist. In their conversation, Max and Sojung explore the unique challenges and opportunities of VR as a storytelling medium.
#BMPDstorytellers https://t.co/FqjXrApVan

Richcraft Hall (formerly the River Building) was designed to celebrate the Rideau River by increasing the greenspace directly beside it. By moving the existing road through the building, a large greenspace is created by the river, perfect for a picnic. 
#carleton_u @jschool_cu https://t.co/rQBmZIZpuB

Richcraft Hall, home of BMPD, was designed by Moriyama & Teshima Architects and completed in 2012. The building contains a large atrium at its centre, designed to be used as an event space with student study spaces on each floor overlooking it. 
#Carleton_U @JSchool_cu https://t.co/MjaNNrL28I

Welcome back from winter break! For the next few days, we will share some information on Richcraft Hall - the home of BMPD. As part of the School of Journalism and Communication, the BMPD program shares many resources with Journalism in the building.
#Carleton_U @jschool_cu https://t.co/nCg7leaEdS

Last day of winter break and last piece of advice! The group Vegan Vampires from the BMPD Media Scavenger Hunt provide four pieces of advice: stay calm, a little bit everyday, talk to your profs, and take care of yourself. 
#BMPDhunt #advice https://t.co/KM4OrKy9tB

BMPD students can all agree that the ITEC courses can be rewarding and challenging. Group Filo Duo from the BMPD Media Scavenger Hunt gives the advice to always brush up on your coding skills to ensure you don't forget it between semesters. 
#BMPDhunt #advice https://t.co/vrY3oiK1pP

Another piece of advice from fellow BMPD students. Group Pepper's Ghosts from the BMPD Media Scavenger Hunt says to do the work on time since there is never enough of it. 
#BMPDhunt #advice https://t.co/Oqpmnr8YVt

Another piece of advice from fellow BMPD students - provided during the BMPD Media Scavenger Hunt in September. 
The group Alpha Fellas gives the advice to new students to always stay organized and ahead of the work. 

#BMPDhunt #advice https://t.co/AH4FZXOj8D

During the BMPD Media Scavenger Hunt in September, we asked groups to give a piece of advice to new BMPD students. 
Over reading week, we will share some of the advice - to help motivate current and future students! First piece of advice is from Group 9.
#BMPDhunt #advice https://t.co/Qx9UedFxIA

Time for another student example and one last look at MPAD1001. The featured autobiographical story sampled here is by first year BMPD student Mya Somogyi. The full video can be watched on the BMPD YouTube channel (link in bio). 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/BAkM6OE15u

Today’s post is all about sharing the ways YOU can get involved with the student society. We are always looking for new members to join our teams and would love to have you on board. To connect with us, head over to Instagram at @BMPD_SS. https://t.co/0BckAnZpE8

We are eager to continue growing the student community around this project in its early days, in order to lay the seeds for future generations of BMPD_SS students. Tune in tomorrow for links of ways to get involved with the student society and have a lasting impact. https://t.co/dty54unVhs

A new student community is forming within the BMPD program and we are super excited to tell you about it! The BMPD Student Society will be taking over this account for 3 days to provide you with information on the new society,  how it impacts you, and how to join!
@jschool_cu https://t.co/HcsRSvX8TO

Have you checked out the new BMPD Storytellers podcast (link in the bio)? This week's episode, Max discusses how philosophy and pop culture connect with artificial intelligence and ethics with Philippe-Antoine Hoyeck. 
 #carleton_u #BMPDstorytellers @fpacu @jschool_cu https://t.co/ymdKvS7j7m

Check out the latest podcast by Storyteller Max Peacock at https://t.co/ixxzHfYnqk
In episode 4 of Our Connected Future, Max is joined by Carleton Instructor, Philippe-Antoine Hoyeck, to discuss AI ethics in pop culture.
 #carleton_u #BMPDstorytellers @fpacu @jschool_cu #podcast https://t.co/wKmuhYgzIt

In MPAD4000: Capstone Projects, the Future Insights video lecture series include guest lectures from industry professionals, such as Danny Williams, Digital Media Artist, who discusses his career at a marketing agency and as a freelancer. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/yVNmtEAj91

Dr. McKnight has been organizing a series of guest lectures and workshops to help students with their experiential and professional learning post graduating - such as this lecture about grad school and why it may be a great option for students! 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/AFLgBxEjFR

Last BMPD core course to spotlight: MPAD4000: Capstone Project, a year-long experiential learning course. MPAD4000 gives MPAD students the opportunity to practice and demonstrate the skills and tools learned throughout their time in the BMPD program.
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/KC63IXuaKF

MPAD3003 workshops have a variety of topics - including one that focuses on creative fun looking maps - with a self-care twist. The  lecture shows how alternative mapping techniques can contribute to self-care rituals and mindfulness. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/QbmoF2UknU

Students in MPAD3002 created a series of podcasts that tell the story of a civic issue or event of their choosing. Specifically, related to their positionalities and experiences. Some are published online at https://t.co/u0tR44ipZ5. Check them out! 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/zq5NLecej0

MPAD 3003 introduces a workshop component to the course. Prof McKnight uses their research-creation and visual arts background to show how to think through creation using  storyboarding, outlining, sketching, and researching. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/WZFtOuqlOL

MPAD3002-3003 are taught by Dr. Stéfy McKnight, a queer, femme of centre white settler artist-scholar. Stéfy uses their background and expertise in research-creation and surveillance to prompt discussion on who is silenced in civic engagement and policy making. 
#BMPDcorecourse https://t.co/HHXnAWkCTm

In third year, students take MPAD3002 and 3003. The course examines the political, cultural, and social events and systems that govern Canada and explore media events and platforms that influence our ways of thinking and engaging with these systems. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/NQpVZSoK3C

MPAD2002 students continue looking at the NAC's art by creating a virtual exhibition using WordPress and @genially_en. Cara Garneau's Jessie Oonark's Untitled Tapestry exhibition uses an interactive comic to explore the history of Inuit art and Cooperatives. 
#BMPDcorecourse https://t.co/UyixTL9iMk

MPAD2001 students use their design and storytelling skills to create a mobile prototype using Adobe XD showcasing visual artwork in the National Arts Centre. The three examples shown here from 2020 are from Aria Zhang, Xinpeng Liu, and Joelle Lui. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/LlqrOCwIk9

MPAD 2001-2002 present information through short asynchronous video lectures followed by discussion and activities in class. As shown in this lecture sample video, the course provides a foundational overview of topics related to visual communication. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/drsBY7iwHh

MPAD2001 & 2002 are taught by Katie Graham who won the “Excellence in Blended and Online Teaching Award" in 2021.  Katie uses a flipped classroom approach moving lectures to before class and reserving class time for activities followed by reflection. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/JMmz7OZKoy

This week we will look at MPAD2001 and 2002: Basics of Visual Communication. The 2nd year courses explore how images communicate through visual and sensory theories and teach how design and composition principles can create compelling visual content. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/EbFlvmga77

Did you guess? The first artwork is real, a wire sculpture by artist David Oliveira and the second image is an AR work titled "Baiser at Mary Boone in Glassish and Waxish" by artist Marjan Moghaddam. The shadows can be deceiving!
#BMPDcorecourses #carleton_u https://t.co/nylbMXxJvm

For the last post about MPAD1002, let's play a game! Each week, students guess between two photographs of artwork which one is a real (physical) installation or an example of AR artwork. Some examples are easier than others! Can you figure it out?
#BMPDcorecourses #carleton_u https://t.co/gnFP25Y55J

Check out this example of a student MPAD1002 project by Tanya Nguyen - an AR travelogue of the Philippines. "The project is a travelogue that is written in a journal. Each journal entry represents a significant event or place that contributes to the narrative." 
#BMPDcorecourse https://t.co/XOjlB8jqtE

Check out this short clip of an MPAD1002 online lecture! The course combines asynchronous online content with live Q&A sessions to let students ask questions, gain further insights on lecture material, and connect with their cohort in real time. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/shLwZa6B6C

MPAD1002: Introduction to Storytelling - the practice is taught by Vicky McArthur,  professor and program director in the BMPD. Her research broadly spans the disciplines of game studies, HCI (human-computer interaction), and immersive storytelling. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/utTpcaJztv

MPAD 1002 leverages the theories and methods introduced in MPAD 1001, to design stories in Augmented Reality (AR). AR is an emerging medium and its narrative affordances continue to evolve with each advancement in computing technologies. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/pGiWlsNMi3

MPAD1001 students learn storytelling techniques which they apply to the final project: an autobiographic animatic about the Covid-19 pandemic. The stories sampled here by Jaden Kidd, Kathleen Padua, and Benjamin Robinson and viewable on the BMPD YouTube channel. 
#carleton_u https://t.co/7knkKGHiTZ

In the fall 2021, MPAD1001 was taught online due to the pandemic. Instructor Bahng made video lectures exploring the fundamentals of storytelling. Watch the 1-min lecture snapshot for a quick overview of the course. 
#BMPDcorecourse #carleton_u https://t.co/xE3OqiyaHC

First year BMPD students take MPAD1001: Intro to Storytelling - the context, taught by Sojung Bahng. The course provides an overview of fact-based digital storytelling and is a great introduction to core principles subsequent BMPD courses build on. 
#carleton_u #BMPDcorecourse https://t.co/2pexzs2CTQ

BMPD students take courses from Information Technology, Journalism, and BMPD. In the core BMPD courses, each year contains courses that build on its predecessor's skills and knowledge. Stay tuned over the next few weeks as we explore each core course. 
#carleton_u https://t.co/YkgjZVnBgb

With the fall term wrapping up, we at BMPD want to wish everyone a happy holidays. The university is closed from December 24th to January 4th. We look forward to sharing more about BMPD in 2022!

As we come to the end of exams, the words self-care are said ALOT! But what is self-care? Professor McKnight stated during her takeover that self-care looks different for everyone. Whatever your self-care is, ensure you devote some time on you during the exam period.

BMPD Scavenger Hunt group Filo Duo provided a list of six things needed to create a great study space that emphasize mindful studying: 
1) a comfortable space
2) a study schedule
3) no distractions
4) planned breaks
5) snacks and water
6) music
#bmpdHUNT #examprep #studyspace https://t.co/2UXuddor6d

One last tip to leave you all with, make sure you enjoy what you are studying. It is perfectly ok to change as many times as you need, but make sure you see yourself in that position or career you have in mind. It will make you happier in the long run.

I hope you guys have been enjoying this week as much as I have. A takeaway from today is to take risks. Take risks with creativity and life. Of course, these are based on circumstances but don’t be afraid to take a chance even if you think it might not be worth it.

Today’s tip deals with groups over remote learning environments. Although it might not be the best circumstance, ensure you create a timeline and have weekly meetings that will discuss your next steps. It’s best to use a form of social media to keep up with things.
